summary: The Industrial Designer gave his presentation on the basic functions of the remote. He presented the basic components that remotes share and suggested that smaller batteries be considered in the product design. The User Interface Designer presented his ideas for making the remote easy-to-use; he discussed using a simple design and hiding complicated features from the main interface. The Marketing Expert presented the findings from a lab study on user requirements for a remote control device, and discussed users' demand for a simple interface and advanced technology. The Project Manager presented the new requirements that the remote not include a teletext function, that it be used only to control television, and that it include the company image in its design. The group narrowed down their target marketing group to the youth market. They discussed the functions the remote will have, including Video Plus capability and rechargeable batteries. A customer service plan was suggested to make the remote seem more user-friendly, but it was decided that helpful manuals were more within the budget. The group then discussed the shell-like shape of the remote and including several different casing options to buyers.
actions: The Marketing Expert will research consumers' opinions on instruction manuals.
decisions: It was decided that the group will produce one product design instead of creating alternate designs in an attempt to accomodate different users' preferences. The marketing will be focused towards a young, business-class buyer. The remote will feature Video Plus capabilities and a seashell-like shape to accomodate the LCD display and the flip screen. The remote will be bundled with a docking station to recharge the remote's batteries and a user-friendly instruction manual, and multiple casings will be made available.
problems: The limitations of the budget will restrict the development of some features; several of the features that the group wanted to include may have to be made simpler to decrease cost.

Meeting 3 was chaired by our Project = Manager,=20 Sarah, and was attended by myself and our 2 Design specialists. Sarah = briefly=20 reviewed the minutes of the last meeting. ES2004docs.ES2004scen.participant2hBcComponents_design.ppt ------------ Components Design Presented by: William Cooke, Industrial Designer Method The press of the button should activate the TV Should be able to find easily Looked into AVAILABILITY of materials Findings Main chip used is a TA11835, these are standard and used in most remote controls. Battery options: Standard AA,AAA Dynamo charging Solar Charging Kinetic Charging Findings Most remotes use a silicon board with rubberised buttons When the button is pressed it sends a unique code to the chip This code is processed then output by the chip and sent via the IR LED to the TV. Personal Preferences To conserve battery life the remote should be in a standby mode while not being used. Case Material? Plastic, Rubber, Wood, Titanium Interface Designs? Rubber buttons, LCD, Bare?? ES2004docs.ES2004scen.participant2hBcfinalpresentation.ppt ------------ Look and Feel Presented by: William Cooke & Pawan Negi, Industrial & Interface Designer Exterior Plastic body: Standard colour: White? Blue? Rubber outer casing (changeable facials) Wide choice of colours, patterns Clamshell design Interior Batteries: Kinetic Voice Recognition: Where is the remote? Im Here!! Standard transmission with TV, using standard chips, PCB etc. Interface Top Screen: B&W LCD Touch screen Bottom Screen: Rubberised Standard Buttons inc. Volume, Power etc. Also containing the new logo! And thats how weve put the fashion back into electronics! ES2004docs.ES2004scen.participant2hBcWorking_design.ppt ------------ Working Design Presented by: William Cooke, Industrial Designer Extraordinaire Method What are we trying to design? -A device which sends a signal to a TV to change its state, (e.g. power button changes on/off and vice versa) Look at what other people have designed and take inspiration Make sure that the new design is original Findings Most remote controls use infrared to send signals to a TV. Most are powered by some form of battery. Small easy to carry round Components Internal: Power Source Batteries Chips To decode the input to IR Signal Sender IR Bulb, Wireless range up to 5m External: Plastic based, UI Design Infrared bulb Bulb Switch Energy source Wire Chip Subcomponent UI Interface TV Receiver IR-Data Personal Preferences Available to a wide audience, cost low. Should be different enough to get a good consumer base. Small, easy to lose? ES2004docs.ES2004scen.participant3hBcInterface_concept..1.ppt ------------ Interface Concept Presented by: Pawan Negi -User Interface Designer Method Input from other departments Marketing and Industrial Design Competitors GUI or Pointing device Findings To many cluttered buttons. Repetition of certain patterns. E.g: The volume and channel control buttons in centre Confusing and inconsistent Voice recognition Personal Preferences Trendy - fruit colour Certain standard buttons Voice recognition ES2004docs.ES2004scen.participant3hBcTechnical_functions..1.ppt ------------ Technical Functions Design Presented by: Pawan Negi, User Interface Designer Method Purpose of Remote Control: To simplify the interaction with TV Main Feature User friendly by being easy-to-use, trendy and engineering marvel. Concept A Flip top model. Main function on the top and complex function inside with browsing facility. Added features such as shock proof body, trendy design. Findings Most people prefer user friendly rather than complex remote controls Economies of scale -Due to high volume, we could produce this design at a cheaper cost. Personal Preferences Flip top design Trendy colours Soft exterior plastic body and soft buttons Thanks you for your attention. Any comments please. ES2004docs.ES2004scen.participant4hBcEvaluation.ppt ------------ Evaluation criteria Presented by: Dale Anderson Marketing Consultant Method Collection of criteria is based on the user requirements and trends found in the marketing reports and the marketing strategy of the Real Reaction electronics company. Findings CRITERIA Fancy look-and-feel Technological innovation Easy to use Incorporates current fashion trends Design minimises RSI Easy to locate Evaluation Criteria rating with seven-point scale 1 = TRUE 7 = FALSE To be continued on whiteboard!
